event.description:
Time Range: 5 and upwards

Mini-golf is a wonderful game for bringing together loved ones of every age. Who doesn’t love besting Dad to the loop-de-loop hole? But it doesn’t ought to be just a vacation-week take care of. Wouldn’t it be great to have your special course to play most of year round—inside or out?

This Old House Video’s plumbing and heating expert, Richard Trethewey, and normal contractor, Tom Silva, designed a great course that friends and family can build in the afternoon. It is comprised of panels that you normally takes apart and rearrange in making the game as easy or hard as you like. Create as many panels because you need for 1, A COUPLE OF, or even 18 divots. Then give everyone the putter, and they’ll possess a ball—literally—trying to navigate the obstacles you place for them.
Rich, Tom, and their crew involving young builders made this mini- course from medium-density fiberboard (MDF), any stable wood composite stuff. It’s smooth and easy to use, and it makes an incredible flat surface for running a golf ball. You will find MDF in several standard sizes with the home center, so you won’t need to cut it up in case you design your course with these sizes planned.

Rich and Tom dealt with the course with environment friendly felt and lined the actual golf holes with PVC pipe fittings. They came up by using two great obstacles—a loop-de-loop along with a ramp with redirects—to challenge even the top putters. You can bring tunnels, water hazards, and ramps for your course, or just use your imagination to set-up different ways to appreciate hours of entertainment in your golf game.
Line up the deck balusters across the edges of a page of MDF. Mark them to fit around the entire linen, corner to corner and flush using the edges.

Using a miter proverbial box and backsaw, cut the particular balusters to length.

Tom Silva pronounces: "Using a miter box fantastic way for kids to learn to saw properly. It controls their workout routines and teaches them that will let the saw do the work. "

Line up the balusters beside the edges of that MDF. Squeeze several strip of wood glue onto each baluster, one baluster at the same time. Leave a few ins of space between this strips of wood glue. In the spaces, put down dabs with fast-setting cyanoacrylate glue.

If you are using two-part cyanoacrylate glue, spray it with activator. Quickly turn with the baluster onto the MDF, tier it up, and hold it in place while the cyanoacrylate sets. This glue acts as being a clamp while the wood glue dries proper strong bond.
Place a 54×72-inch piece of felt on a worktable. Extend it slightly, and hold it into position with spring clamps.

Place the MDF on a plastic drop cloth, from the the felt. Spray the top of the MDF with adhesive. Work in lengthy, even strokes across the entire board. Spray the felt with adhesive as well. Let both pieces dry in line with the instructions on this can.
